results.title: Amour de la toilette
results.brief_description:
Subtlety is the key to this brilliantly conceived hand drawn animation that employs the simple technology of a whiteboard and markers to create an engaging evocation of Paris. The use of minimalist materials is supported by thorough planning skills, the controlled use of camera and a storyline that is achievable within the limitations of the medium.
Music by The Cafe Accordian Orchestra.

results.title: Amore
results.brief_description:
Michel, a young architect is sent by the French government to Venice with a mision to try and find a solution to save an island. Paolo, a young photographer, offers to help Michel in his discovery of the city. He also introduces him to the beautiful Marina.

Credits: Director, Henry Chapier ; writers, Anne Capelle, Henry Chapier ; photoraphy, Alain Derobe ; music, Vangelis Papathanassiou.
Cast: Sonia Petrova, Daniel Quenaud, Julian Negulesco, Henri Deus, Daniel Ceccaldi.

results.title: Amongst equals
results.creator_credit: Tom Zubrycki, Paul Hamfess and Jotz Productions
results.brief_description: Documents the history of the Australian Trade Union Movement. The film is not endorsed by the ACTU and represents only the film maker’s view. The 1850s saw the introduction of the eight hour labour movement and the subsequent development of the trade union movement. Unions were established to organise, assert and defend the worker’s rights, industrial awards, occupational health and safety and minimum wages.

results.title: Among the wild chimpanzees
results.creator_credit: Barbara Jampel and National Geographic Society
results.brief_description: Presents an account of Jane Goodall’s continuing research project with wild chimpanzees in Tanzania. Details her discoveries that chimpanzees not only use but also make tools, they hunt meat and even kill one another. They also suffer from infectious human diseases. Suitable for Upper Primary and Secondary School students.

results.title: Among the living
results.creator_credit: Osborn Segerberg and United Nations Television
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Man builds - man destroys”.
Raises the question of whether there is such a thing as an “optimum” world population, while looking closely at the town of Huntington on Long Island, one of the many satellite communities surrounding New York City. Presents the views on population of such noted authorities as Paul Ehrlich, Barry Commoner, Philip Hauser, Alan Guttmacher and Lincoln Day. Hosted by Don Pringle.

results.title: Among the Hardwoods
results.creator_credit: Lyn Maplestone and Commonwealth of Australia
results.brief_description: An earlier silent version of this film was made in 1927 as part of the ‘Know Your Own Country’ series by renowned pioneer cinematographer Lacey Percival. In mid-1936 Bert Ive and a sound recordist revisited the Pemberton region of south-west Western Australia where they filmed and also recorded natural sounds from the forest. Whilst this re-edited film was half the length of the original, Ive’s director Lyn Maplestone created greater impact by lingering on the sights and sounds of logging trees in the Jarrah and Karri forests. The film focuses on the atmosphere of the forest as it was irrevocably changed by the axe and saw of the loggers. Scenes shot for the silent version (but not always used) can also be seen being processed and screened in ‘Telling the World’ (1929). Source: NFSA Film Australia Collection.

results.title: Among giants
results.creator_credit: Sam Miller, Stephen Garrett, YMPA, BBC Film Unit, Kudos, Capitol Films and Fox Searchlight Pictures
results.brief_description: From the writer of “The Full monty”, Simon Beaufoy, comes “Among giants”, a tale set in Sheffield, England about a group of unemployed blue-collar workers who take on odd jobs to make ends meet. The latest of these high risk ventures is an unofficial contract to paint miles of power towers on the remote and beautiful Yorkshire Moors. The group are an eclectic mix of ageing hippies and adrenalin seeking rock climbers, very laddish in their encounters with one another. Into this all male crew enters Gerry (Rachel Griffiths) a feisty, fearless, mountain climbing Australian backpacker, who upsets the working life and social order of the group. Gerry falls for her boss Ray (Pete Postlethwaite) fuelling problems for both of them with his ex-wife, and with his best friend, Steven. Tensions rise as racing against the clock, the crew strives to complete the job, whilst Ray and Gerry struggle to resolve the status of their relationship. Billed as a romantic comedy, the film is situated in the tradition of light hearted tales of the woes of English working class life.

results.title: Among fish
results.creator_credit: Kenneth McCready, Rene Jodoin and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: A demonstration, for junior science classes, of what fish are, how they live, breathe, swim and, more remarkable, how they float up or down by manipulating their air bladder. The fish shown in the film are of the kind native to Canada’s lakes and streams, but others, of the tropical variety, are observed in the miniature marine world of a classroom aquarium. Suitable for middle and upper primary levels.

results.title: Amoeba
results.brief_description: This one-celled organism has been photographed as a solid object and not, as diagrammatic represent- ations suggest, a flat object in one plane. The production of pseudopods is shown - the amoeba pursuing and capturing its prey and ingesting living organisms
